awd_abstract_narration: The work supported by this award is a continuation of ongoing                   research in computational astronomy.  In the area of radio pulsar               searches, highly-successful work in detecting globular cluster                  pulsars, with emphasis on very deep searches of globular cluster                cores, wide area searches of globular cluster halos, and greatly                improved searches for short-period binary pulsars will be pursued.              In the area of diffraction-limited imaging, improved algorithms                 for bispectral imaging including use of maximum entropy methods and             extension of the algorithms to radio interferometers will be                    developed.  In addition to these specific efforts, the potential                of future high-performance parallel computers for observational                 astronomy research will be investigated.  In particular, Caltech                plans to acquire a next-generation Intel parallel supercomputer                 which will have -100 times the computing capability of current-                 generation machines.  Such a computer will provide significant new              possibilities for astronomical research.  Promising new                         applications for this machine, and specific hardware and software               tools needed for astronomical computing will be identified. //
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences
